list.text: He is not only dull himself, he is the cause of dullness in others.
list.author: Samuel Johnson

list.text:
He laughs at every joke three times... once when it's told, once when
it's explained, and once when he understands it.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: He looked at me as if I were a side dish he hadn't ordered.
list.author: Ring Lardner

list.text: He missed an invaluable opportunity to hold his tongue.
list.author: Andrew Lang

list.text:
He only knew his iron spine held up the sky -- he didn't realize his brain
had fallen to the ground.
list.author: The Book of Serenity

list.text: He thinks by infection, catching an opinion like a cold.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: He walks as if balancing the family tree on his nose.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: He was so narrow-minded he could see through a keyhole with both eyes.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: He who always plows a straight furrow is in a rut.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: He who despises himself nevertheless esteems himself as a self-despiser.
list.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

list.text: He who hoots with owls by night cannot soar with eagles by day.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: He who is flogged by fate and laughs the louder is a masochist.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: He who is good for making excuses is seldom good for anything else.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: He who is known as an early riser need not get up until noon.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: He who minds his own business is never unemployed.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: He who walks on burning coals is sure to get burned.
list.author: Sinbad

list.text: He who wonders discovers that this in itself is wonder.
list.author: M.C. Escher

list.text:
He's the kind of guy, that, well, if you were ever in a jam he'd
be there... with two slices of bread and some chunky peanut butter.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: "He's the kind of man for the times that need the kind of man he is ..."
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Her days were spent in a kind of slow bustle; always busy without getting
on, always behind hand and lamenting it, without altering her ways;
wishing to be an economist, without contrivance or regularity; dissatisfied
with her servants, without skill to make them better, and whether helping, or
reprimanding, or indulging them, without any power of engaging their respect.
list.author: J. Austen

list.text:
Here I am, fifty-eight, and I still don't know what I want to be when
I grow up.
list.author: Peter Drucker

list.text:
Hi!  I'm Larry.  This is my brother Bob, and this is my other brother
Jimbo.  We thought you might like to know the names of your assailants.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Higgins:	Doolittle, you're either an honest man or a rogue.
Doolittle:	A little of both, Guv'nor.  Like the rest of us, a
		little of both.
list.author: Shaw, "Pygmalion"

list.text: Hindsight is always 20:20.
list.author: Billy Wilder

list.text: Hindsight is an exact science.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: His life was formal; his actions seemed ruled with a ruler.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: His mind is like a steel trap: full of mice.
list.author: Foghorn Leghorn

list.text:
History repeats itself -- the first time as a tragi-comedy, the second
time as bedroom farce.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: History repeats itself only if one does not listen the first time.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: History repeats itself.  That's one thing wrong with history.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Home is the place where, when you have to go there, they have to take you in.
list.author: Robert Frost, "The Death of the Hired Man"

list.text:
Home life as we understand it is no more natural to us than a cage is
to a cockatoo.
list.author: George Bernard Shaw

list.text: Hope is a good breakfast, but it is a bad supper.
list.author: Francis Bacon

list.text: Hope is a waking dream.
list.author: Aristotle

list.text: Hope not, lest ye be disappointed.
list.author: M. Horner

list.text:
How comes it to pass, then, that we appear such cowards in reasoning,
and are so afraid to stand the test of ridicule?
list.author: A. Cooper

list.text: How long a minute is depends on which side of the bathroom door you're on.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: How many "coming men" has one known!  Where on earth do they all go to?
list.author: Sir Arthur Wing Pinero

list.text:
However, never daunted, I will cope with adversity in my traditional
manner ... sulking and nausea.
list.author: Tom K. Ryan

list.text: Human kind cannot bear very much reality.
list.author: T.S. Eliot, "Four Quartets: Burnt Norton"

list.text:
Humanity has advanced, when it has advanced, not because it has been sober, 
responsible, and cautious, but because it has been playful, rebellious, and 
immature.
list.author: Tom Robbins

list.text: Humans are communications junkies.  We just can't get enough.
list.author: Alan Kay

list.text: Humility is the first of the virtues -- for other people.
list.author: Oliver Wendell Holmes

list.text:
I allow the world to live as it chooses, and I allow myself to live as I
choose.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
I always choose my friends for their good looks and my enemies for their
good intellects.  Man cannot be too careful in his choice of enemies.
list.author: Oscar Wilde, "The Picture of Dorian Gray"

list.text:
I always pass on good advice.  It is the only thing to do with it.
It is never any good to oneself.
list.author: Oscar Wilde, "An Ideal Husband"

list.text: I always say beauty is only sin deep.
list.author: Saki, "Reginald's Choir Treat"

list.text: I am an optimist.  It does not seem too much use being anything else.
list.author: Winston Churchill

list.text: I am firm.  You are obstinate.  He is a pig-headed fool.
list.author: Katharine Whitehorn

list.text: I am looking for a honest man.
list.author: Diogenes the Cynic

list.text:
"I am ready to meet my Maker.  Whether my Maker is prepared for the
great ordeal of meeting me is another matter."
list.author: Winston Churchill

list.text: I believe in getting into hot water; it keeps you clean.
list.author: G.K. Chesterton

list.text: I call them as I see them.  If I can't see them, I make them up.
list.author: Biff Barf

list.text: I can give you my word, but I know what it's worth and you don't.
list.author: Nero Wolfe, "Over My Dead Body"

list.text:
I can write better than anybody who can write faster, and I can write
faster than anybody who can write better.
list.author: A.J. Liebling

list.text:
I can't seem to bring myself to say, "Well, I guess I'll be toddling along."
It isn't that I can't toddle.  It's that I can't guess I'll toddle.
list.author: Robert Benchley

list.text: I can't stand squealers; hit that guy.
list.author: Albert Anastasia

list.text:
I can't understand it.  I can't even understand the people who can
understand it.
list.author: Queen Juliana of the Netherlands.

list.text:
I can't understand why people are frightened of new ideas.  I'm frightened
of the old ones.
list.author: John Cage

list.text: I cannot and will not cut my conscience to fit this year's fashions.
list.author: Lillian Hellman

list.text:
I consider the day misspent that I am not either charged with a crime,
or arrested for one.
list.author: "Ratsy" Tourbillon

list.text:
I didn't get sophisticated -- I just got tired.  But maybe that's what
sophisticated is -- being tired.
list.author: Rita Gain

list.text: "I didn't know it was impossible when I did it."
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
I disagree with what you say, but will defend to the death your right to
tell such LIES!
list.author: Unknow

list.text: I do not know myself and God forbid that I should.
list.author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

list.text:
I do not know where to find in any literature, whether ancient or modern,
any adequate account of that nature with which I am acquainted.  Mythology
comes nearest to it of any.
list.author: Henry David Thoreau

list.text:
"I don't know what you mean by 'glory'," Alice said.
	Humpty Dumpty smiled contemptuously.  "Of course you don't --
till I tell you.  I meant 'there's a nice knock-down argument for you!'"
	"But glory doesn't mean 'a nice knock-down argument'," Alice
objected.
	"When I use a word," Humpty Dumpty said, in a rather scornful
tone, "it means just what I choose it to mean -- neither more nor less."
	"The question is," said Alice, "whether you can make words mean
so many different things."
	"The question is," said Humpty Dumpty, "which is to be master --
that's all."
list.author: Lewis Carrol, "Through the Looking Glass"

list.text:
I don't know who my grandfather was; I am much more concerned to know
what his grandson will be.
list.author: Abraham Lincoln

list.text: I don't know why we're here, I say we all go home and free associate.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: I don't make the rules, Gil, I only play the game.
list.author: Cash McCall

list.text: I don't mind arguing with myself.  It's when I lose that it bothers me.
list.author: Richard Powers

list.text: I don't remember it, but I have it written down.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
"I don't think they could put him in a mental hospital.  On the other
hand, if he were already in, I don't think they'd let him out."
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
"I don't understand," said the scientist, "why you lemmings all rush down
to the sea and drown yourselves."
"How curious," said the lemming. "The one thing I don't understand is why
you human beings don't."
list.author: James Thurber

list.text: I don't want to bore you, but there's nobody else around for me to bore.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: I either want less decadence or more chance to participate in it.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: I generally avoid temptation unless I can't resist it.
list.author: Mae West

list.text: I give you the man who -- the man who -- uh, I forgets the man who?
list.author: Beauregard Bugleboy

list.text: I got vision, and the rest of the world wears bifocals.
list.author: Butch Cassidy

list.text:
I guess I've been wrong all my life, but so have billions of other people...
Certainty is just an emotion.
list.author: Hal Clement

list.text:
I hate mankind, for I think myself one of the best of them, and I know
how bad I am.
list.author: Samuel Johnson

list.text:
I hate small towns because once you've seen the cannon in the park
there's nothing else to do.
list.author: Lenny Bruce

list.text:
I have discovered that all human evil comes from this, man's being unable
to sit still in a room.
list.author: Blaise Pascal

list.text:
I have found little that is good about human beings.  In my experience
most of them are trash.
list.author: Sigmund Freud

list.text: I have great faith in fools -- self confidence my friends call it.
list.author: Edgar Allan Poe

list.text:
I have learned silence from the talkative,
toleration from the intolerant, and kindness from the unkind.
list.author: Kahlil Gibran

list.text:
I have made mistakes but I have never made the mistake of claiming
that I have never made one.
list.author: James Gordon Bennett

list.text:
I have no right, by anything I do or say, to demean a human being in his
own eyes.  What matters is not what I think of him; it is what he thinks
of himself.  To undermine a man's self-respect is a sin.
list.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupery

list.text:
I knew one thing: as soon as anyone said you didn't need a gun, you'd better
take one along that worked.
list.author: Raymond Chandler

list.text: I love mankind ... It's people I hate.
list.author: Schulz

list.text:
I made it a rule to forbear all direct contradictions to the sentiments
of others, and all positive assertion of my own.  I even forbade myself the use
of every word or expression in the language that imported a fixed opinion, such
as "certainly", "undoubtedly", etc.   I adopted instead of them "I conceive",
"I apprehend", or "I imagine" a thing to be so or so; or "so it appears to me
at present".
	When another asserted something that I thought an error, I denied
myself the pleasure of contradicting him abruptly, and of showing him
immediately some absurdity in his proposition.  In answering I began by
observing that in certain cases or circumstances his opinion would be right,
but in the present case there appeared or semed to me some difference, etc.
	I soon found the advantage of this change in my manner; the
conversations I engaged in went on more pleasantly.  The modest way in which I
proposed my opinions procured them a readier reception and less contradiction.
I had less mortification when I was found to be in the wrong, and I more easily
prevailed with others to give up their mistakes and join with me when I
happened to be in the right.
list.author: Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin

list.text:
"I may appear to be just sitting here like a bucket of tapioca, but don't
let appearances fool you.  I'm approaching old age ... at the speed of light."
list.author: Prof. Cosmo Fishhawk

list.text: I may be getting older, but I refuse to grow up!
list.author: Unknow

list.text: I may not be totally perfect, but parts of me are excellent.
list.author: Ashleigh Brilliant

list.text: I never killed a man that didn't deserve it.
list.author: Mickey Cohen

list.text: I prefer rogues to imbeciles because they sometimes take a rest.
list.author: Alexandre Dumas, fils

list.text: I profoundly believe it takes a lot of practice to become a moral slob.
list.author: William F. Buckley

list.text:
I put the shotgun in an Adidas bag and padded it out with four pairs of
tennis socks, not my style at all, but that was what I was aiming for:  If
they think you're crude, go technical; if they think you're technical, go
crude.  I'm a very technical boy.  So I decided to get as crude as possible.
These days, though, you have to be pretty technical before you can even
aspire to crudeness.
list.author: William Gibson, "Johnny Mnemonic"

list.text:
"... I should explain that I was wearing a black velvet cape that was
supposed to make me look like the dashing, romantic Zorro but which actually
made me look like a gigantic bat wearing glasses ..."
		   Points in l'Amour"
list.author: Dave Barry, "The Wet Zorro Suit and Other Turning

list.text: I sometimes think that God, in creating man, somewhat overestimated his ability.
list.author: Oscar Wilde

list.text:
I think I'm schizophrenic.  One half of me's paranoid and the other half's
out to get him.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
I treasure this strange combination found in very few persons: a fierce
desire for life as well as a lucid perception of the ultimate futility of
the quest.
list.author: Madeleine Gobeil

list.text:
I used to think that the brain was the most wonderful organ in
my body.  Then I realized who was telling me this.
list.author: Emo Phillips

list.text: I waited and waited and when no message came I knew it must be from you.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
I will follow the good side right to the fire, but not into it if I can
help it.
list.author: Michel Eyquem de Montaigne

list.text:
I'll defend to the death your right to say that, but I never said I'd
listen to it!
list.author: Tom Galloway with apologies to Voltaire

list.text:
I'll give you my opinion of the human race in a nutshell ... their heart's
in the right place, but their head is a thoroughly inefficient organ.
list.author: W. Somerset Maugham, "The Summing Up"

list.text: I'll pretend to trust you if you'll pretend to trust me.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
I'm not the person your mother warned you about... her imagination isn't
that good.
list.author: Amy Gorin

list.text:
"I'm really enjoying not talking to you ... Let's not talk again ____    REAL
soon ..."
list.author: Unknow

list.text: I'm so miserable without you, it's almost like you're here.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: I'm sorry if the correct way of doing things offends you.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: I'm sorry, but my karma just ran over your dogma.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: I'm successful because I'm lucky.   The harder I work, the luckier I get.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: I've already told you more than I know.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
I've found my niche.  If you're wondering why I'm not there, there was
this little hole in the bottom ...
list.author: John Croll

list.text: I've given up reading books; I find it takes my mind off myself.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
I've known him as a man, as an adolescent and as a child -- sometimes
on the same day.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: "I've seen, I SAY, I've seen better heads on a mug of beer"
list.author: Senator Claghorn

list.text:
Ideas don't stay in some minds very long because they don't like
solitary confinement.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If a man has talent and cannot use it, he has failed.
list.author: Thomas Wolfe

list.text: If God had intended Man to Walk, He would have given him Feet.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If God had meant for us to be naked, we would have been born that way.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If God had really intended men to fly, he'd make it easier to get to the
airport.
list.author: George Winters

list.text: If God had wanted you to go around nude, He would have given you bigger hands.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If God hadn't wanted you to be paranoid, He wouldn't have given you such
a vivid imagination.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If God wanted us to be brave, why did he give us legs?
list.author: Marvin Kitman

list.text:
If he should ever change his faith, it'll be because he no longer thinks
he's God.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If I'm over the hill, why is it I don't recall ever being on top?
list.author: Jerry Muscha

list.text: If man is only a little lower than the angels, the angels should reform.
list.author: Mary Wilson Little

list.text: If one studies too zealously, one easily loses his pants.
list.author: A. Einstein.

list.text:
If one tells the truth, one is sure, sooner or later, to be found out.
		of the Young"
list.author: Oscar Wilde, "Phrases and Philosophies for the Use

list.text: If only I could be respected without having to be respectable.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If only one could get that wonderful feeling of accomplishment without
having to accomplish anything.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If only you had a personality instead of an attitude.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If opportunity came disguised as temptation, one knock would be enough.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If people are good only because they fear punishment, and hope for reward,
then we are a sorry lot indeed.
list.author: Albert Einstein

list.text:
If people see that you mean them no harm, they'll never hurt you, nine
times out of ten!
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If practice makes perfect, and nobody's perfect, why practice?
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If some people didn't tell you, you'd never know they'd been away on vacation.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If someone says he will do something "without fail", he won't.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If the weather is extremely bad, church attendance will be down.  If
the weather is extremely good, church attendance will be down.  If the
bulletin covers are in short supply, however, church attendance will
exceed all expectations.
list.author: Reverend Chichester

list.text: If there is a wrong way to do something, then someone will do it.
list.author: Edward A. Murphy Jr.

list.text: If there was any justice in the world, "trust" would be a four-letter word.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If things don't improve soon, you'd better ask them to stop helping you.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: "If we were meant to fly, we wouldn't keep losing our luggage."
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If we were meant to get up early, God would have created us with alarm clocks.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you are a fatalist, what can you do about it?
list.author: Ann Edwards-Duff

list.text: If you are honest because honesty is the best policy, your honesty is corrupt.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If you can keep your head when all about you are losing theirs, then
you clearly don't understand the situation.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you can't say anything good about someone, sit right here by me.
list.author: Alice Roosevelt Longworth

list.text:
If you cannot in the long run tell everyone what you have been doing,
your doing was worthless.
list.author: Edwim Schrodinger

list.text: If you continually give you will continually have.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you didn't get caught, did you really do it?
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If you didn't have most of your friends, you wouldn't have most of
your problems.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If you do not wish a man to do a thing, you had better get him to talk about
it; for the more men talk, the more likely they are to do nothing else.
list.author: Carlyle

list.text: If you don't care where you are, then you ain't lost.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If you don't do it, you'll never know what would have happened if you
had done it.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you don't do the things that are not worth doing, who will?
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you don't go to other men's funerals they won't go to yours.
list.author: Clarence Day

list.text: If you don't have a nasty obituary you probably didn't matter.
list.author: Freeman Dyson

list.text: If you don't like the way I drive, stay off the sidewalk!
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you don't say anything, you won't be called on to repeat it.
list.author: Calvin Coolidge

list.text: If you explain so clearly that nobody can misunderstand, somebody will.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you flaunt it, expect to have it trashed.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If you float on instinct alone, how can you calculate the buoyancy for
the computed load?
list.author: Christopher Hodder-Williams

list.text:
If you go out of your mind, do it quietly, so as not to disturb those
around you.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you had any brains, you'd be dangerous.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If you just try long enough and hard enough, you can always manage to
boot yourself in the posterior.
list.author: A.J. Liebling, "The Press"

list.text:
If you keep your mind sufficiently open, people will throw a lot of
rubbish into it.
list.author: William Orton

list.text:
If you lived today as if it were your last, you'd buy up a box of rockets
and fire them all off, wouldn't you?
list.author: Garrison Keillor

list.text: If you look good and dress well, you don't need a purpose in life.
list.author: Robert Pante, fashion consultant

list.text:
If you make people think they're thinking, they'll love you; but if you
really make them think they'll hate you.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you mess with a thing long enough, it'll break.
list.author: Schmidt

list.text:
If you notice that a person is deceiving you, they must not be
deceiving you very well.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If you talk to God, you are praying; if God talks to you, you have
schizophrenia.
list.author: Thomas Szasz

list.text: If you think before you speak the other guy gets his joke in first.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you think the problem is bad now, just wait until we've solved it.
list.author: Arthur Kasspe

list.text:
If you think things can't get worse it's probably only because you
lack sufficient imagination.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you try to please everyone, somebody is not going to like it.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you want to know how old a man is, ask his brother-in-law.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If you will practice being fictional for a while, you will understand that
fictional characters are sometimes more real than people with bodies and
heartbeats.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If you would understand your own age, read the works of fiction produced
in it.  People in disguise speak freely.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you're careful enough, nothing bad or good will ever happen to you.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you're constantly being mistreated, you're cooperating with the treatment.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
If you're going to do something tonight that you'll be sorry for tomorrow
morning, sleep late.
list.author: Henny Youngman

list.text: If you're happy, you're successful.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: If you're not very clever you should be conciliatory.
list.author: Benjamin Disraeli

list.text:
In good speaking, should not the mind of the speaker know the truth of
the matter about which he is to speak?
list.author: Plato

list.text:
In matters of principle, stand like a rock;
in matters of taste, swim with the current.
list.author: Thomas Jefferson

list.text: In most instances, all an argument proves is that two people are present.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: In success there's a tendency to keep on doing what you were doing.
list.author: Alan Kay

list.text:
In the misfortune of our friends we find something that is not displeasing
to us.
list.author: La Rochefoucauld, "Maxims"

list.text:
In this world some people are going to like me and some are not.  So, I may
as well be me.  Then I know if someone likes me, they like me.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
In this world there are only two tragedies.  One is not getting what one
wants, and the other is getting it.
list.author: Oscar Wilde

list.text: Innocence ends when one is stripped of the delusion that one likes oneself.
list.author: Joan Didion, "On Self Respect"

list.text: Intolerance is the last defense of the insecure.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Involvement with people is always a very delicate thing --
it requires real maturity to become involved and not get all messed up.
list.author: Bernard Cooke

list.text: It destroys one's nerves to be amiable every day to the same human being.
list.author: Benjamin Disraeli

list.text:
It does not matter if you fall down as long as you pick up something
from the floor while you get up.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
It doesn't matter what you do, it only matters what you say you've
done and what you're going to do.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
It has been observed that one's nose is never so happy as when it is
thrust into the affairs of another, from which some physiologists have
drawn the inference that the nose is devoid of the sense of smell.
list.author: Ambrose Bierce, "The Devil's Dictionary"

list.text:
It has been said that man is a rational animal.  All my life I have
been searching for evidence which could support this.
list.author: Bertrand Russell

list.text:
It is all right to hold a conversation, but you should let go of it
now and then.
list.author: Richard Armour

list.text:
It is always the best policy to tell the truth, unless, of course,
you are an exceptionally good liar.
list.author: Jerome K. Jerome

list.text: It is amazing how complete is the delusion that beauty is goodness.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
It is better for civilization to be going down the drain than to be 
coming up it.
list.author: Henry Allen

list.text: It is easier to get forgiveness than permission.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: It is easier to make a saint out of a libertine than out of a prig.
list.author: George Santayana

list.text: It is easy when we are in prosperity to give advice to the afflicted.
list.author: Aeschylus

list.text:
It is equally bad when one speeds on the guest unwilling to go, and when he
holds back one who is hastening.  Rather one should befriend the guest who
is there, but speed him when he wishes.
 
	[Quoted in "VMS Internals and Data Structures", V4.4, when
	 referring to scheduling.]
list.author: Homer, "The Odyssey"

list.text: It is exactly because a man cannot do a thing that he is a proper judge of it.
list.author: Oscar Wilde

list.text:
It is far more impressive when others discover your good qualities without
your help.
list.author: Miss Manners

list.text:
It is generally agreed that "Hello" is an appropriate greeting because
if you entered a room and said "Goodbye," it could confuse a lot of people.
list.author: Dolph Sharp, "I'm O.K., You're Not So Hot"

list.text: It is impossible for an optimist to be pleasantly surprised.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: It is impossible to make anything foolproof because fools are so ingenious.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
It is indeed desirable to be well descended, but the glory belongs to
our ancestors.
list.author: Plutarch

list.text: It is much easier to be critical than to be correct.
list.author: Benjamin Disraeli

list.text: It is not enough to have a good mind. The main thing is to use it well.
list.author: Rene Descartes

list.text:
It is not enough to have great qualities, we should also have the
management of them.
list.author: La Rochefoucauld

list.text:
It is not good for a man to be without knowledge,
and he who makes haste with his feet misses his way.
list.author: Proverbs 19:2

list.text: It is often easier to ask for forgiveness than to ask for permission.
list.author: Grace Murray Hopper

list.text: It is one thing to praise discipline, and another to submit to it.
list.author: Cervantes

list.text: It is only people of small moral stature who have to stand on their dignity.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
It is only the great men who are truly obscene.  If they had not dared
to be obscene, they could never have dared to be great.
list.author: Havelock Ellis

list.text: It is the business of little minds to shrink.
list.author: Carl Sandburg

list.text:
It is the nature of extreme self-lovers, as they will set an house on fire,
and it were but to roast their eggs.
list.author: Francis Bacon

list.text: It is the wisdom of crocodiles, that shed tears when they would devour.
list.author: Francis Bacon

list.text: It is the wise bird who builds his nest in a tree.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: It matters not whether you win or lose; what matters is whether I I win or lose.
list.author: Darrin Weinberg

list.text:
It may be bad manners to talk with your mouth full, but it isn't too
good either if you speak when your head is empty.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
It may be that your whole purpose in life is simply to serve as a
warning to others.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: It pays to be obvious, especially if you have a reputation for subtlety.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
It seemed the world was divided into good and bad people.  The good ones slept
better... while the bad ones seemed to enjoy the waking hours much more.
list.author: Woody Allen, "Side Effects"

list.text: It seems to make an auto driver mad if he misses you.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: It takes a special kind of courage to face what we all have to face.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: It takes all kinds to fill the freeways.
list.author: Crazy Charlie

list.text: It takes both a weapon, and two people, to commit a murder.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
It takes less time to do a thing right than it does to explain why you
did it wrong.
list.author: H.W. Longfellow

list.text: It takes two to tell the truth: one to speak and one to hear.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
It will be generally found that those who sneer habitually at human nature
and affect to despise it, are among its worst and least pleasant examples.
list.author: Charles Dickens

list.text: It would be nice to be sure of anything the way some people are of everything.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
It's amazing how many people you could be friends with if only they'd
make the first approach.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: It's amazing how much "mature wisdom" resembles being too tired.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: It's amazing how nice people are to you when they know you're going away.
list.author: Michael Arlen

list.text: It's bad enough that life is a rat-race, but why do the rats always have to win?
list.author: Unknow

list.text: It's better to be quotable than to be honest.
list.author: Tom Stoppard

list.text: It's better to be wanted for murder that not to be wanted at all.
list.author: Marty Winch

list.text: It's easier to fight for one's principles than to live up to them.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
It's easier to get forgiveness for being wrong than forgiveness for being 
right.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: It's hard not to like a man of many qualities, even if most of them are bad.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: It's hard to be humble when you're perfect.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: It's hard to keep your shirt on when you're getting something off your chest.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
It's interesting to think that many quite distinguished people have
bodies similar to yours.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
It's only by NOT taking the human race seriously that I retain
what fragments of my once considerable mental powers I still possess.
list.author: Roger Noe

list.text:
It's reassuring to know that if you behave strangely enough, society will
take full responsibility for you.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: It's sweet to be remembered, but it's often cheaper to be forgotten.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Jealousy is all the fun you think they have.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Just because I turn down a contract on a guy doesn't mean he isn't going
to get hit.
list.author: Joey

list.text: Just because you're paranoid doesn't mean they AREN'T after you.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
"Just out of curiosity does this actually mean something or have some
of the few remaining bits of your brain just evaporated?"
list.author: Patricia O Tuama, rissa@killer.DALLAS.TX.US

list.text:
Just weigh your own hurt against the hurt of all the others, and then
do what's best.
list.author: Lovers and Other Strangers

list.text: Just when you thought you were winning the rat race, along comes a faster rat!!
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Justice always prevails ... three times out of seven!
list.author: Michael J. Wagner

list.text: Keep cool, but don't freeze.
list.author: Hellman's Mayonnaise

list.text:
Keep your mouth shut and people will think you stupid;
Open it and you remove all doubt.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Lack of capability is usually disguised by lack of interest.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Lack of money is the root of all evil.
list.author: George Bernard Shaw

list.text:
Largest Number of Driving Test Failures
	By April 1970 Mrs. Miriam Hargrave had failed her test thirty-nine
times.  In the eight preceding years she had received two hundred and
twelve driving lessons at a cost of L300.  She set the new record while
driving triumphantly through a set of red traffic lights in Wakefield,
Yorkshire.  Disappointingly, she passed at the fortieth attempt (3 August
1970) but eight years later she showed some of her old magic when she was
reported as saying that she still didn't like doing right-hand turns.
list.author: Stephen Pile, "The Book of Heroic Failures"

list.text: Last guys don't finish nice.
list.author: Stanley Kelley, on the cult of victory at all costs

list.text: Laughter is the closest distance between two people.
list.author: Victor Borge

list.text: Learn from other people's mistakes, you don't have time to make your own.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Let a fool hold his tongue and he will pass for a sage.
list.author: Publilius Syrus

list.text: Let the meek inherit the earth -- they have it coming to them.
list.author: James Thurber

list.text: Let's do it.
list.author: Gary Gilmore, to his firing squad

list.text:
Life is a hospital in which every patient is possessed by the desire to
change his bed.
list.author: Charles Baudelaire

list.text: Life is a series of rude awakenings.
list.author: R.V. Winkle

list.text:
Life is a serious burden, which no thinking, humane person would
wantonly inflict on someone else.
list.author: Clarence Darrow

list.text: Life is an exciting business, and most exciting when it is lived for others.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Life is like bein' on a mule team.  Unless you're the lead mule, all the
scenery looks about the same.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
"Life would be much simpler and things would get done much faster if it
weren't for other people"
list.author: Blore

list.text:
Like my parents, I have never been a regular church member or churchgoer.
It doesn't seem plausible to me that there is the kind of God who watches
over human affairs, listens to prayers, and tries to guide people to follow
His precepts -- there is just too much misery and cruelty for that.  On the
other hand, I respect and envy the people who get inspiration from their
religions.
list.author: Benjamin Spock

list.text:
Looking for a cool one after a long, dusty ride, the drifter strode
into the saloon.  As he made his way through the crowd to the bar, a man
galloped through town screaming, "Big Mike's comin'!  Run fer yer lives!"
	Suddenly, the saloon doors burst open.  An enormous man, standing over
eight feet tall and weighing an easy 400 pounds, rode in on a bull, using a
rattlesnake for a whip.  Grabbing the drifter by the arm and throwing him over
the bar, the giant thundered, "Gimme a drink!"
	The terrified man handed over a bottle of whiskey, which the man
guzzled in one gulp and then smashed on the bar.  He then stood aghast as
the man stuffed the broken bottle in his mouth, munched broken glass and
smacked his lips with relish.
	"Can I, ah, uh, get you another, sir?" the drifter stammered.
	"Naw, I gotta git outa here, boy," the man grunted.  "Big Mike's
a-comin'."
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Lord, defend me from my friends; I can account for my enemies.
list.author: Charles D'Hericault

list.text: Love thy neighbor as thyself, but choose your neighborhood.
list.author: Louise Beal

list.text: Love your enemies: they'll go crazy trying to figure out what you're up to.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Love your neighbour, yet don't pull down your hedge.
list.author: Benjamin Franklin

list.text: Lying is an indispensable part of making life tolerable.
list.author: Bergan Evans

list.text: Make no little plans; they have no magic to stir men's blood.
list.author: Daniel Hudson Burnham

list.text: Man belongs wherever he wants to go.
list.author: Wernher von Braun

list.text: Man has made his bedlam; let him lie in it.
list.author: Fred Allen

list.text: Man has never reconciled himself to the ten commandments.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Man invented language to satisfy his deep need to complain.
list.author: Lily Tomlin

list.text:
Man is a rational animal who always loses his temper when he is called upon
to act in accordance with the dictates of reason.
list.author: Oscar Wilde

list.text:
Man is the only animal that can remain on friendly terms with the
victims he intends to eat until he eats them.
list.author: Samuel Butler (1835-1902)

list.text:
Man is the only animal that laughs and weeps; for he is the only animal
that is struck with the difference between what things are and what they
ought to be.
list.author: William Hazlitt

list.text:
Man usually avoids attributing cleverness to somebody else -- unless it
is an enemy.
list.author: Albert Einstein

list.text: Man's horizons are bounded by his vision.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Man's unique agony as a species consists in his perpetual conflict between
the desire to stand out and the need to blend in.
list.author: Sydney J. Harris

list.text: Many a family tree needs trimming.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Many a man that can't direct you to a corner drugstore will get a respectful
hearing when age has further impaired his mind.
list.author: Finley Peter Dunne

list.text:
Many mental processes admit of being roughly measured.  For instance,
the degree to which people are bored, by counting the number of their
fidgets. I not infrequently tried this method at the meetings of the
Royal Geographical Society, for even there dull memoirs are occasionally
read.  [...]  The use of a watch attracts attention, so I reckon time
by the number of my breathings, of which there are 15 in a minute.  They
are not counted mentally, but are punctuated by pressing with 15 fingers
successively.  The counting is reserved for the fidgets.  These observations
should be confined to persons of middle age.  Children are rarely still,
while elderly philosophers will sometimes remain rigid for minutes altogether.
list.author: Francis Galton, 1909

list.text:
Many people are desperately looking for some wise advice which will
recommend that they do what they want to do.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Many people are secretly interested in life.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Many people feel that if you won't let them make you happy, they'll make you
suffer.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Many people feel that they deserve some kind of recognition for all the
bad things they haven't done.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Many people resent being treated like the person they really are.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Many receive advice, few profit by it.
list.author: Publilius Syrus

list.text: 'Martyrdom' is the only way a person can become famous without ability.
list.author: George Bernard Shaw

list.text:
May those that love us love us; and those that don't love us, may
God turn their hearts; and if he doesn't turn their hearts, may
he turn their ankles so we'll know them by their limping.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: May you die in bed at 95, shot by a jealous spouse.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Maybe Jesus was right when he said that the meek shall inherit the
earth -- but they inherit very small plots, about six feet by three.
list.author: Lazarus Long

list.text: "Maybe we can get together and show off to each other sometimes."
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Meekness is uncommon patience in planning a worthwhile revenge.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Men ought to know that from the brain and from the brain only arise our
pleasures, joys, laughter, and jests as well as our sorrows, pains, griefs
and tears.  ...  It is the same thing which makes us mad or delirious,
inspires us with dread and fear, whether by night or by day, brings us
sleeplessness, inopportune mistakes, aimless anxieties, absent-mindedness
and acts that are contrary to habit...
list.author: Hippocrates "The Sacred Disease"

list.text:
Men use thought only to justify their wrong doings, and speech only to
conceal their thoughts.
list.author: Voltaire

list.text:
Millions long for immortality who do not know what to do with themselves on a
rainy Sunday afternoon.
list.author: Susan Ertz

list.text: Mind your own business, then you don't mind mine.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Mix a little foolishness with your serious plans; it's lovely to be silly
at the right moment.
list.author: Horace

list.text: Modern man is the missing link between apes and human beings.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Modesty is a vastly overrated virtue.
list.author: J.K. Galbraith

list.text: More are taken in by hope than by cunning.
list.author: Vauvenargues

list.text: More people are flattered into virtue than bullied out of vice.
list.author: R.S. Surtees

list.text:
Most of our lives are about proving something, either to ourselves or to
someone else.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Most of the fear that spoils our life comes from attacking difficulties
before we get to them.
list.author: Dr. Frank Crane

list.text: Most of your faults are not your fault.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Most people are too busy to have time for anything important.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Most people are unable to write because they are unable to think, and
they are unable to think because they congenitally lack the equipment
to do so, just as they congenitally lack the equipment to fly over the moon.
list.author: H.L. Mencken

list.text: Most people can do without the essentials, but not without the luxuries.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Most people can't understand how others can blow their noses differently
than they do.
list.author: Turgenev

list.text: Most people deserve each other.
list.author: Shirley

list.text: Most people feel that everyone is entitled to their opinion.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Most people have a furious itch to talk about themselves and are restrained
only by the disinclination of others to listen.  Reserve is an artificial
quality that is developed in most of us as the result of innumerable rebuffs.
list.author: W.S. Maugham

list.text: Most people have a mind that's open by appointment only.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Most people have two reasons for doing anything -- a good reason, and
the real reason.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Most people in this society who aren't actively mad are, at best,
reformed or potential lunatics.
list.author: Susan Sontag

list.text:
Most people need some of their problems to help take their mind off
some of the others.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Most people prefer certainty to truth.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Mother told me to be good but she's been wrong before.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Murder is always a mistake -- one should never do anything one cannot
talk about after dinner.
list.author: Oscar Wilde, "The Picture of Dorian Gray"

list.text: My brain is my second favorite organ.
list.author: Woody Allen

list.text:
My method is to take the utmost trouble to find the right thing to say.
And then say it with the utmost levity.
list.author: G.B. Shaw

list.text:
My mind can never know my body, although it has become quite friendly
with my legs.
list.author: Woody Allen, on Epistemology

list.text: My opinions may have changed, but not the fact that I am right.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: My own business always bores me to death; I prefer other people's.
list.author: Oscar Wilde

list.text: My philosophy is: Don't think.
list.author: Charles Manson

list.text:
Nearly all men can stand adversity, but if you want to test a man's
character, give him power.
list.author: Abraham Lincoln

list.text: Needs are a function of what other people have.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Neither spread the germs of gossip nor encourage others to do so.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Never argue with a fool -- people might not be able to tell the difference.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Never argue with a man who buys ink by the barrel.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Never ask the barber if you need a haircut.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Never explain.  Your friends do not need it and your enemies will never
believe you anyway.
list.author: Elbert Hubbard

list.text: Never face facts; if you do you'll never get up in the morning.
list.author: Marlo Thomas

list.text: Never forget what a man says to you when he is angry.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Never frighten a small man -- he'll kill you.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Never get into fights with ugly people because they have nothing to lose.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Never insult an alligator until you've crossed the river.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Never kick a man, unless he's down.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Never leave anything to chance; make sure all your crimes are premeditated.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Never pay a compliment as if expecting a receipt.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Never speak ill of yourself, your friends will always say enough on
that subject.
list.author: Charles-Maurice De Talleyrand

list.text: Never tell a lie unless it is absolutely convenient.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Never trust anybody whose arm is bigger than your leg.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Never underestimate the power of human stupidity.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Never, ever lie to someone you love unless you're absolutely sure they'll
never find out the truth.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Nezvannyi gost'--khuzhe tatarina.
	[An uninvited guest is worse than the Mongol invasion]
list.author: Russian proverb

list.text: Nice boy, but about as sharp as a sack of wet mice.
list.author: Foghorn Leghorn

list.text:
No character, however upright, is a match for constantly reiterated attacks,
however false.
list.author: Alexander Hamilton

list.text:
No guest is so welcome in a friend's house that he will not become a
nuisance after three days.
list.author: Titus Maccius Plautus

list.text: No man is an island, but some of us are long peninsulas.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: No man is useless who has a friend, and if we are loved we are indispensable.
list.author: Robert Louis Stevenson

list.text: No man would listen to you talk if he didn't know it was his turn next.
list.author: E.W. Howe

list.text: No matter what happens, there is always someone who knew it would.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: No one becomes depraved in a moment.
list.author: Decimus Junius Juvenalis

list.text:
No one can have a higher opinion of him than I have, and I think he's a
dirty little beast.
list.author: W.S. Gilbert

list.text: No one can make you feel inferior without your consent.
list.author: Eleanor Roosevelt

list.text: No one can put you down without your full cooperation.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: "No one gets too old to learn a new way of being stupid."
list.author: Unknow

list.text: No one knows what he can do till he tries.
list.author: Publilius Syrus

list.text: No one regards what is before his feet; we all gaze at the stars.
list.author: Quintus Ennius

list.text:
No one so thoroughly appreciates the value of constructive criticism as the
one who's giving it.
list.author: Hal Chadwick

list.text: No question is so difficult as one to which the answer is obvious.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: No snowflake in an avalanche ever feels responsible.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: No sooner said than done -- so acts your man of worth.
list.author: Quintus Ennius

list.text: Nobody can be as agreeable as an uninvited guest.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Nobody ever forgets where he buried the hatchet.
list.author: Kin Hubbard

list.text:
Nobody is one block of harmony.  We are all afraid of something, or feel
limited in something.  We all need somebody to talk to.  It would be good
if we talked to each other--not just pitter-patter, but real talk.  We
shouldn't be so afraid, because most people really like this contact;
that you show you are vulnerable makes them free to be vulnerable too.
It's so much easier to be together when we drop our masks.
list.author: Liv Ullman

list.text: Nobody knows the trouble I've been.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Nobody knows what goes between his cold toes and his warm ears.
list.author: Roy Harper

list.text:
Nobody wants constructive criticism.  It's all we can do to put up with
constructive praise.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Nothing astonishes men so much as common sense and plain dealing.
list.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

list.text:
Nothing makes one so vain as being told that one is a sinner.
Conscience makes egotists of us all.
list.author: Oscar Wilde

list.text:
Nothing shortens a journey so pleasantly as an account of misfortunes at
which the hearer is permitted to laugh.
list.author: Quentin Crisp

list.text:
O Lord, grant that we may always be right, for Thou knowest we will
never change our minds.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Objects are lost only because people look where they are not rather than
where they are.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Obstacles are what you see when you take your eyes off your goal.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Oh this age!  How tasteless and ill-bred it is.
list.author: Gaius Valerius Catullus

list.text:
Oh wearisome condition of humanity!
Born under one law, to another bound.
list.author: Fulke Greville, Lord Brooke

list.text:
"Oh, yes.  The important thing about having lots of things to  remember is
that you've got to go somewhere afterwards where you can remember them, you
see?  You've got to stop.  You haven't really been anywhere until you've got
back home.  I think that's what I mean."
list.author: Terry Pratchett, "The Light Fantastic"

list.text: Old age and treachery will overcome youth and skill.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Old age is always fifteen years old than I am.
list.author: B. Baruch

list.text: Old age is the harbor of all ills.
list.author: Bion

list.text: Old age is the most unexpected of things that can happen to a man.
list.author: Trotsky

list.text: Old age is too high a price to pay for maturity.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Old men are fond of giving good advice to console themselves for their
inability to set a bad example.
list.author: La Rochefoucauld, "Maxims"

list.text:
On Monday mornings I am dedicated to the proposition that all men are
created jerks.
list.author: H. Allen Smith, "Let the Crabgrass Grow"

list.text:
One advantage of talking to yourself is that you know at least somebody's
listening.
list.author: Franklin P. Jones

list.text: One can never consent to creep when one feels an impulse to soar.
list.author: Helen Keller

list.text: One family builds a wall, two families enjoy it.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
One friend in a lifetime is much; two are many; three are hardly possible.
Friendship needs a certain parallelism of life, a community of thought,
a rivalry of aim.
list.author: Henry Brook Adams

list.text: One is not superior merely because one sees the world as odious.
list.author: Chateaubriand (1768-1848)

list.text: One is often kept in the right road by a rut.
list.author: Gustave Droz

list.text: One man tells a falsehood, a hundred repeat it as true.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
One measure of friendship consists not in the number of things friends
can discuss, but in the number of things they need no longer mention.
list.author: Clifton Fadiman

list.text: One nice thing about egotists: they don't talk about other people.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
One of the large consolations for experiencing anything unpleasant is
the knowledge that one can communicate it.
list.author: Joyce Carol Oates

list.text:
One of the major difficulties Trillian experienced in her relationship with
Zaphod was learning to distinguish between him pretending to be stupid just
to get people off their guard, pretending to be stupid because he couldn't
be bothered to think and wanted someone else to do it for him, pretending
to be so outrageously stupid to hide the fact that he actually didn't
understand what was going on, and really being genuinely stupid.  He was
reknowned for being quite clever and quite clearly was so -- but not all the
time, which obviously worried him, hence the act.  He preferred people to be
puzzled rather than contemptuous.  This above all appeared to Trillian to be
genuinely stupid, but she could no longer be bothered to argue about.
list.author: Douglas Adams, "The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy"

list.text:
One of the pleasures of reading old letters is the knowledge that they
need no answer.
list.author: George Gordon, Lord Byron

list.text: One of the worst of my many faults is that I'm too critical of myself.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
One would like to stroke and caress human beings, but one dares not do so,
because they bite.
list.author: Vladimir Il'ich Lenin

list.text: Only a fool has no doubts.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Only a mediocre person is always at his best.
list.author: Laurence Peter

list.text: Only fools are quoted.
list.author: Anonymous

list.text:
Only kings, presidents, editors, and people with tapeworms have the right
to use the editorial "we".
list.author: Mark Twain

list.text:
Only someone with nothing to be sorry for smiles back at the rear of an
elephant.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Only the hypocrite is really rotten to the core.
list.author: Hannah Arendt

list.text:
Only two of my personalities are schizophrenic, but one of them is
paranoid and the other one is out to get him.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Optimism is the content of small men in high places.
list.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald, "The Crack Up"

list.text:
Original thought is like original sin: both happened before you were born
to people you could not have possibly met.
list.author: Fran Lebowitz, "Social Studies"

list.text: Others can stop you temporarily, only you can do it permanently.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Others will look to you for stability, so hide when you bite your nails.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Out of the crooked timber of humanity no straight thing can ever be made.
list.author: Immanuel Kant

list.text: Paranoia doesn't mean the whole world isn't out to get you.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Paranoia is heightened awareness.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Paranoia is simply an optimistic outlook on life.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Paranoid schizophrenics outnumber their enemies at least two to one.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Paranoids are people, too; they have their own problems.  It's easy
to criticize, but if everybody hated you, you'd be paranoid too.
list.author: D.J. Hicks

list.text: Passionate hatred can give meaning and purpose to an empty life.
list.author: Eric Hoffer

list.text: Patience is a minor form of despair, disguised as virtue.
list.author: Ambrose Bierce, on qualifiers

list.text:
Pelorat sighed.
	"I will never understand people."
	"There's nothing to it.  All you have to do is take a close look
at yourself and you will understand everyone else.  How would Seldon have
worked out his Plan -- and I don't care how subtle his mathematics was --
if he didn't understand people; and how could he have done that if people
weren't easy to understand?  You show me someone who can't understand
people and I'll show you someone who has built up a false image of himself
-- no offense intended."
list.author: Asimov, "Foundation's Edge"

list.text:
People (a group that in my opinion has always attracted an undue amount of
attention) have often been likened to snowflakes.  This analogy is meant to
suggest that each is unique -- no two alike.  This is quite patently not the
case.  People ... are simply a dime a dozen.  And, I hasten to add, their
only similarity to snowflakes resides in their invariable and lamentable
tendency to turn, after a few warm days, to slush.
list.author: Fran Lebowitz, "Social Studies"

list.text: People are like onions -- you cut them up, and they make you cry.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: People are unconditionally guaranteed to be full of defects.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: People don't change; they only become more so.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
People don't usually make the same mistake twice -- they make it three
times, four time, five times...
list.author: Unknow

list.text: People love high ideals, but they got to be about 33-percent plausible.
list.author: The Best of Will Rogers

list.text: People need good lies.  There are too many bad ones.
list.author: Bokonon, "Cat's Cradle" by Kurt Vonnegut, Jr.

list.text:
People often find it easier to be a result of the past than a cause of the
future.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: People respond to people who respond.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
People say I live in my own little fantasy world... well, at least they
*know* me there!
list.author: D.L. Roth

list.text:
People seem to enjoy things more when they know a lot of other people
have been left out on the pleasure.
list.author: Russell Baker

list.text: People tend to make rules for others and exceptions for themselves.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
People who claim they don't let little things bother them have never
slept in a room with a single mosquito.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: People who fight fire with fire usually end up with ashes.
list.author: Abigail Van Buren

list.text:
People who have no faults are terrible; there is no way of taking
advantage of them.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
People who have what they want are very fond of telling people who haven't
what they want that they don't want it.
list.author: Ogden Nash

list.text: People who make no mistakes do not usually make anything.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: People who push both buttons should get their wish.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: People who take cat naps don't usually sleep in a cat's cradle.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: People who take cold baths never have rheumatism, but they have cold baths.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: People who think they know everything greatly annoy those of us who do.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
People will accept your ideas much more readily if you tell them that Benjamin
Franklin said it first.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
People will do tomorrow what they did today because that is what they
did yesterday.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: People with narrow minds usually have broad tongues.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Perhaps the world's second worst crime is boredom.  The first is being a bore.
list.author: Cecil Beaton

list.text: Personifiers of the world, unite!  You have nothing to lose but Mr. Dignity!
list.author: Bernadette Bosky

list.text:
Please don't put a strain on our friendship by asking me to do something
for you.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Please don't recommend me to your friends-- it's difficult enough to
cope with you alone.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Please forgive me if, in the heat of battle, I sometimes forget which
side I'm on.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Practically perfect people never permit sentiment to muddle their thinking.
list.author: Mary Poppins

list.text: Pretend to spank me -- I'm a pseudo-masochist!
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Progress is impossible without change, and those who cannot change their
minds cannot change anything.
list.author: G.B. Shaw

list.text: Put your brain in gear before starting your mouth in motion.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Put your trust in those who are worthy.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Questions are never indiscreet, answers sometimes are.
list.author: Oscar Wilde

list.text:
"Quite frankly, I don't like you humans.  After what you all have done,
I find being 'inhuman' a compliment."
list.author: Spider Robinson, "Callahan's Secret"

list.text: Rarely do people communicate; they just take turns talking.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Relations are simply a tedious pack of people, who haven't the remotest
knowledge of how to live, nor the smallest instinct about when to die.
list.author: Oscar Wilde, "The Importance of Being Earnest"

list.text:
... relaxed in the manner of a man who has no need to put up a front of
any kind.
list.author: John Ball, "Mark One: the Dummy"

list.text: Remember: Silly is a state of Mind, Stupid is a way of Life.
list.author: Dave Butler

list.text: Revenge is a form of nostalgia.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Revenge is a meal best served cold.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
"Richard, in being so fierce toward my vampire, you were doing
what you wanted to do, even though you thought it was going to hurt
somebody else. He even told you he'd be hurt if..."
	"He was going to suck my blood!"
	"Which is what we do to anyone when we tell them we'll be hurt
if they don't live our way."
...
	"The thing that puzzles you," he said, "is an accepted saying that
happens to be impossible.  The phrase is hurt somebody else.  We choose,
ourselves, to be hurt or not to be hurt, no matter what.  Us who decides.
Nobody else.  My vampire told you he'd be hurt if you didn't let him?  That's
his decision to be hurt, that's his choice.  What you do about it is your
decision, your choice: give him blood; ignore him; tie him up; drive a stake
through his heart.  If he doesn't want the holly stake, he's free to resist,
in whatever way he wants.  It goes on and on, choices, choices."
	"When you look at it that way..."
	"Listen," he said, "it's important.  We are all.  Free.  To do.
Whatever.  We want.  To do."
list.author: Richard Bach, "Illusions"

list.text:
Rincewind looked down at him and grinned slowly.  It was a wide, manic, and
utterly humourless rictus.  It was the sort of grin that is normally
accompanied by small riverside birds wandering in and out, picking scraps
out of the teeth.
list.author: Terry Pratchett, "The Lure of the Wyrm"

list.text: Rudeness is a weak man's imitation of strength.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Saints should always be judged guilty until they are proved innocent.
list.author: George Orwell, "Reflections on Gandhi"

list.text: Sanity and insanity overlap a fine grey line.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Sanity is the trademark of a weak mind.
list.author: Mark Harrold

list.text: Say no, then negotiate.
list.author: Helga

list.text: Say something you'll be sorry for, I love receiving apologies.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Scenery is here, wish you were beautiful.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Schizophrenia beats being alone.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Screw up your courage!  You've screwed up everything else.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: "See - the thing is - I'm an absolutist.  I mean, kind of ... in a way ..."
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Sentimentality -- that's what we call the sentiment we don't share.
list.author: Graham Greene

list.text: Serenity through viciousness.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Shall we make a new rule of life from tonight: always to try to be a
little kinder than is necessary?
list.author: J.M. Barrie

list.text: Shame is an improper emotion invented by pietists to oppress the human race.
list.author: Robert Preston, Toddy, "Victor/Victoria"

list.text: She often gave herself very good advice (though she very seldom followed it).
list.author: Lewis Carroll

list.text: Short people get rained on last.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Show your affection, which will probably meet with pleasant response.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Sin boldly.
list.author: Martin Luther

list.text: Sin has many tools, but a lie is the handle which fits them all.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Sin lies only in hurting other people unnecessarily.  All other "sins" are
invented nonsense.  (Hurting yourself is not sinful -- just stupid).
list.author: Lazarus Long

list.text: Since we have to speak well of the dead, let's knock them while they're alive.
list.author: John Sloan

list.text: Since we're all here, we must not be all there.
list.author: Bob "Mountain" Beck

list.text: Sinners can repent, but stupid is forever.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
So far as we are human, what we do must be either evil or good: so far
as we do evil or good, we are human: and it is better, in a paradoxical
way, to do evil than to do nothing: at least we exist.
list.author: T.S. Eliot, essay on Baudelaire

list.text:
So live that you wouldn't be ashamed to sell the family parrot to the
town gossip.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Some don't prefer the pursuit of happiness to the happiness of pursuit.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Some men are born mediocre, some men achieve mediocrity, and some men
have mediocrity thrust upon them.
list.author: Joseph Heller, "Catch-22"

list.text: Some men are discovered; others are found out.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Some men love truth so much that they seem to be in continual fear
lest she should catch a cold on overexposure.
list.author: Samuel Butler

list.text:
Some of the things that live the longest in peoples' memories never
really happened.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Some people around here wouldn't recognize subtlety if it hit them on the head.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Some people cause happiness wherever they go; others, whenever they go.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Some people have a way about them that seems to say: "If I have
only one life to live, let me live it as a jerk."
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Some people have parts that are so private they themselves have no
knowledge of them.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Some people's mouths work faster than their brains.  They say things they
haven't even thought of yet.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Some rise by sin and some by virtue fall.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Someone will try to honk your nose today.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Something better...
 1 (obvious): Excuse me.  Is that your nose or did a bus park on your face?
 2 (meteorological): Everybody take cover.  She's going to blow.
 3 (fashionable): You know, you could de-emphasize your nose if you wore 
	something larger.  Like ... Wyoming.
 4 (personal): Well, here we are.  Just the three of us.
 5 (punctual): Alright gentlemen.  Your nose was on time but you were fifteen
	minutes late.
 6 (envious): Oooo, I wish I were you.  Gosh.  To be able to smell your
	own ear.
 7 (naughty): Pardon me, Sir.  Some of the ladies have asked if you wouldn't
	mind putting that thing away.
 8 (philosophical): You know.  It's not the size of a nose that's important.
	It's what's in it that matters.
 9 (humorous): Laugh and the world laughs with you.  Sneeze and it's goodbye,
	Seattle.
10 (commercial): Hi, I'm Earl Schibe and I can paint that nose for $39.95.
11 (polite): Ah.  Would you mind not bobbing your head.  The orchestra keeps
	changing tempo.
12 (melodic): Everybody! "He's got the whole world in his nose."
list.author: Steve Martin, "Roxanne"

list.text:
Something better...
13 (sympathetic): Oh, What happened?  Did your parents lose a bet with God?
14 (complimentary): You must love the little birdies to give them this to
	perch on.
15 (scientific): Say, does that thing there influence the tides?
16 (obscure): Oh, I'd hate to see the grindstone.
17 (inquiry): When you stop to smell the flowers, are they afraid?
18 (french): Say, the pigs have refused to find any more truffles until you
	leave.
19 (pornographic): Finally, a man who can satisfy two women at once.
20 (religious): The Lord giveth and He just kept on giving, didn't He.
21 (disgusting): Say, who mows your nose hair?
22 (paranoid): Keep that guy away from my cocaine!
23 (aromatic): It must be wonderful to wake up in the morning and smell the
	coffee ... in Brazil.
24 (appreciative): Oooo, how original.  Most people just have their teeth
	capped.
25 (dirty): Your name wouldn't be Dick, would it?
list.author: Steve Martin, "Roxanne"

list.text: Something unpleasant is coming when men are anxious to tell the truth.
list.author: Benjamin Disraeli

list.text:
Sometimes I get the feeling that I went to a party on Perry Lane in 1962, and
the party spilled out of the house, and came down the street, and covered the
world.
list.author: Robert Stone

list.text: Sometimes I worry about being a success in a mediocre world.
list.author: Lily Tomlin

list.text:
Sometimes when you look into his eyes you get the feeling that someone
else is driving.
list.author: David Letterman

list.text: Speak softly and carry a +6 two-handed sword.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Speak softly and own a big, mean Doberman.
list.author: Dave Millman

list.text: Start every day off with a smile and get it over with.
list.author: W.C. Fields

list.text: Start the day with a smile.  After that you can be your nasty old self again.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Stay together, drag each other down.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Still looking for the glorious results of my misspent youth.  Say, do you
have a map to the next joint?
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Stupidity got us into this mess -- why can't it get us out?
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Stupidity is its own reward.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Style may not be the answer, but at least it's a workable alternative.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Subtlety is the art of saying what you think and getting out of the way
before it is understood.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Success is a journey, not a destination.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Success is getting what you want; happiness is wanting what you get.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Success is in the minds of Fools.
list.author: William Wrenshaw, 1578

list.text: Success is relative: It is what we can make of the mess we have made of things.
list.author: T.S. Eliot, "The Family Reunion"

list.text: Succumb to natural tendencies.  Be hateful and boring.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Such a fine first dream!
But they laughed at me; they said
I had made it up.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Suicide is simply a case of mistaken identity.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Suicide is the sincerest form of self-criticism.
list.author: Donald Kaul

list.text: Support your local Search and Rescue unit -- get lost.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Sure he's sharp as a razor ... he's a two-dimensional pinhead!
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Surly to bed, surly to rise, makes you about average.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Tact in audacity is knowing how far you can go without going too far.
list.author: Jean Cocteau

list.text:
Tact is the ability to tell a man he has an open mind when he has a
hole in his head.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Tact is the art of making a point without making an enemy.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Take a lesson from the whale; the only time he gets speared is when he
raises to spout.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Talk is cheap because supply always exceeds demand.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Talk sense to a fool and he calls you foolish.
list.author: Euripides

list.text: Talking much about oneself can also be a means to conceal oneself.
list.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

list.text:
Tart words make no friends; a spoonful of honey will catch more flies than
a gallon of vinegar.
list.author: B. Franklin

list.text:
Tell a man there are 300 billion stars in the universe and he'll believe you.
Tell him a bench has wet paint on it and he'll have to touch to be sure.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: Tell me what to think!!!
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
Telling the truth to people who misunderstand you is generally promoting
a falsehood, isn't it?
list.author: A. Hope

list.text: "That boy's about as sharp as a pound of wet liver"
list.author: Foghorn Leghorn

list.text: That must be wonderful: I don't understand it at all.
list.author: Moliere

list.text: That which is not good for the swarm, neither is it good for the bee.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
That's always the way when you discover something new; everyone thinks
you're crazy.
list.author: Evelyn E. Smith

list.text:
The adjuration to be "normal" seems shockingly repellent to me; I see neither
hope nor comfort in sinking to that low level.  I think it is ignorance that
makes people think of abnormality only with horror and allows them to remain
undismayed at the proximity of "normal" to average and mediocre.  For surely
anyone who achieves anything is, essentially, abnormal.
list.author: Dr. Karl Menninger, "The Human Mind", 1930

list.text:
The aim of a joke is not to degrade the human being but to remind him that
he is already degraded.
list.author: George Orwell

list.text: The angry man always thinks he can do more than he can.
list.author: Albertano of Brescia

list.text: The average nutritional value of promises is roughly zero.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
The average, healthy, well-adjusted adult gets up at seven-thirty in
the morning feeling just terrible.
list.author: Jean Kerr

list.text: The best laid plans of mice and men are usually about equal.
list.author: Blair

list.text:
The best portion of a good man's life, his little, nameless, unremembered acts
of kindness and love.
list.author: Wordsworth

list.text:
The best that we can do is to be kindly and helpful toward our friends and
fellow passengers who are clinging to the same speck of dirt while we are
drifting side by side to our common doom.
list.author: Clarence Darrow

list.text: The best thing about growing older is that it takes such a long time.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: The best way to get rid of worries is to let them die of neglect.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: The best way to keep your friends is not to give them away.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: The bigger they are, the harder they hit.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: The biggest problem with communication is the illusion that it has occurred.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: The bland leadeth the bland and they both shall fall into the kitsch.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
The brotherhood of man is not a mere poet's dream; it is a most depressing
and humiliating reality.
list.author: Oscar Wilde

list.text:
The correct way to punctuate a sentence that starts: "Of course it is none
of my business, but --" is to place a period after the word "but."  Don't use
excessive force in supplying such a moron with a period.  Cutting his throat
is only a momentary pleasure and is bound to get you talked about.
list.author: Lazarus Long, "Time Enough for Love"

list.text: The difference between a good haircut and a bad one is seven days.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
The difference between common-sense and paranoia is that common-sense is
thinking everyone is out to get you.  That's normal -- they are.  Paranoia
is thinking that they're conspiring.
list.author: J. Kegler

list.text: The difference between genius and stupidity is that genius has its limits.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
The difference between sentiment and being sentimental is the following:
Sentiment is when a driver swerves out of the way to avoid hitting a
rabbit on the road.  Being sentimental is when the same driver, when
swerving away from the rabbit hits a pedestrian.
list.author: Frank Herbert, "The White Plague"

list.text: The discerning person is always at a disadvantage.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
The distinction between true and false appears to become increasingly
blurred by... the pollution of the language.
list.author: Arne Tiselius

list.text: The end of the human race will be that it will eventually die of civilization.
list.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

list.text:
The forest is safe because a lion lives therein and the lion is safe because
it lives in a forest.  Likewise the friendship of persons rests on mutual help.
list.author: Laukikanyay.

list.text:
The full potentialities of human fury cannot be reached until a friend
of both parties tactfully interferes.
list.author: G.K. Chesterton

list.text:
The Golden Rule is of no use to you whatever unless you realize it
is your move.
list.author: Frank Crane

list.text: The great merit of society is to make one appreciate solitude.
list.author: Charles Chincholles, "Reflections on the Art of Life"

list.text:
The great secret in life ... [is] not to open your letters for a fortnight.
At the expiration of that period you will find that nearly all of them have
answered themselves.
list.author: Arthur Binstead

list.text: The greatest of faults is to be conscious of none.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: The greatest remedy for anger is delay.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
The hardest thing is to disguise your feelings when you put a lot of
relatives on the train for home.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: The hatred of relatives is the most violent.
list.author: Tacitus (c.55 - c.117)

list.text: ... the heat come 'round and busted me for smiling on a cloudy day.
list.author: Unknow

list.text: The help people need most urgently is help in admitting that they need help.
list.author: Unknow

list.text:
The heroic hours of life do not announce their presence by drum and trumpet,
challenging us to be true to ourselves by appeals to the martial spirit that
keeps the blood at heat.  Some little, unassuming, unobtrusive choice presents
itself before us slyly and craftily, glib and insinuating, in the modest garb
of innocence.  To yield to its blandishments is so easy.  The wrong, it seems,
is venial...  Then it is that you will be summoned to show the courage of
adventurous youth.
